meaning: The word 'able' means having the power, skill, means, or opportunity to do something. It implies competence or capability in a particular area.
etymology: The word 'able' originates from the Latin word 'habilis', meaning 'easily handled, apt, fit', which itself comes from 'habere', meaning 'to hold'. It entered Middle English via Old French 'able'.
sentences: She is able to solve complex problems with ease.
To be able to dream is to be able to achieve.
short_stories: Once upon a time, a small bird believed it was able to fly across the vast ocean. Despite the doubts of others, it took a leap of faith and, after many trials, succeeded, proving that belief and ability can overcome any obstacle.
In a small village, a young boy was told he would never be able to read. Determined, he spent every evening practicing, and years later, he became the village's most beloved storyteller.
poetry: I think that I shall never see / A poem lovely as a tree. / A tree whose hungry mouth is prest / Against the earth’s sweet flowing breast; / A tree that looks at God all day, / And lifts her leafy arms to pray; / A tree that may in Summer wear / A nest of robins in her hair; / Upon whose bosom snow has lain; / Who intimately lives with rain. / Poems are made by fools like me, / But only God can make a tree. - Joyce Kilmer

Do not go gentle into that good night, / Old age should burn and rave at close of day; / Rage, rage against the dying of the light. / Though wise men at their end know dark is right, / Because their words had forked no lightning they / Do not go gentle into that good night. - Dylan Thomas
